original_text: The GFRFs of nonlinear systems can be determined by either a parametric-model-based method or a nonparametric-model-based method [8]. In the parametric approach, a nonlinear parametric model is first identified from the input–output data. The GFRFs are then obtained by mapping the resultant model into the frequency domain using the probing method [9]. The nonparametric approach is often referred to as frequency-domain Volterra system identification and is based on the observation that the Volterra model of nonlinear systems is linear in terms of the unknown Volterra kernels, which, in the frequency domain, corresponds to a linear relation between the output frequency response and linear, quadratic, and higher order GFRFs. This linear relationship allows the use of a least squares (LS) approach to solve for the GFRFs. Several researchers [10–12] have used this method to estimate the GFRFs. But they usually made the assumption that it is known a priori that the system under study can be represented by just two or three terms. However, such information is rarely available a priori.
original_translation: Los GFRFs de sistemas no lineales pueden determinarse mediante un método basado en modelos paramétricos o un método basado en modelos no paramétricos [8]. En el enfoque paramétrico, primero se identifica un modelo paramétrico no lineal a partir de los datos de entrada y salida. Los GFRFs se obtienen luego al mapear el modelo resultante al dominio de frecuencia utilizando el método de sondeo [9]. El enfoque no paramétrico se conoce comúnmente como identificación de sistemas de Volterra en el dominio de la frecuencia y se basa en la observación de que el modelo de Volterra de sistemas no lineales es lineal en términos de los núcleos de Volterra desconocidos, lo que, en el dominio de la frecuencia, corresponde a una relación lineal entre la respuesta en frecuencia de salida y las GFRFs lineales, cuadráticas y de orden superior. Esta relación lineal permite el uso de un enfoque de mínimos cuadrados (LS) para resolver los GFRFs. Varios investigadores [10–12] han utilizado este método para estimar los GFRFs. Pero generalmente asumían que se sabe a priori que el sistema en estudio puede ser representado por solo dos o tres términos. Sin embargo, esta información rara vez está disponible de antemano.

This linear relationship allows the use of a least squares (LS) approach to solve for the GFRFs.
Several researchers [10–12] have used this method to estimate the GFRFs.
But they usually made the assumption that it is known a priori that the system under study can be represented by just two or three terms.
However, such information is rarely available a priori.

El enfoque no paramétrico se conoce comúnmente como identificación de sistemas de Volterra en el dominio de la frecuencia y se basa en la observación de que el modelo de Volterra de sistemas no lineales es lineal en términos de los núcleos de Volterra desconocidos, lo que, en el dominio de la frecuencia, corresponde a una relación lineal entre la respuesta en frecuencia de salida y las GFRFs lineales, cuadráticas y de orden superior. Esta relación lineal permite el uso de un enfoque de mínimos cuadrados (LS) para resolver los GFRFs. Varios investigadores [10–12] han utilizado este método para estimar los GFRFs. Output: Pero generalmente
hacen la suposición
de que se sabe de antemano que el sistema bajo estudio puede ser representado por solo dos o tres términos. Sin embargo, esta información rara vez está disponible de antemano.

mapping the resultant model into the fre.translated_key: mapear el modelo resultante en el dominio de frecuencia
original_annotated_sentences: The GFRFs of nonlinear systems can be determined by either a parametric-model-based method or a nonparametric-model-based method [8].
In the parametric approach, a nonlinear parametric model is first identified from the input–output data.

The GFRFs are then obtained by
mapping the resultant model into the frequency domain
using the probing method [9].

The nonparametric approach is often referred to as frequency-domain Volterra system identification and is based on the observation that the Volterra model of nonlinear systems is linear in terms of the unknown Volterra kernels, which, in the frequency domain, corresponds to a linear relation between the output frequency response and linear, quadratic, and higher order GFRFs.
This linear relationship allows the use of a least squares (LS) approach to solve for the GFRFs.
Several researchers [10–12] have used this method to estimate the GFRFs.
But they usually made the assumption that it is known a priori that the system under study can be represented by just two or three terms.
However, such information is rarely available a priori.

The GFRFs of nonlinear systems.translated_key: Los GFRFs de sistemas no lineales
original_annotated_sentences:
The GFRFs of nonlinear systems
can be determined by either a parametric-model-based method or a nonparametric-model-based method [8].
In the parametric approach, a nonlinear parametric model is first identified from the input–output data.
The GFRFs are then obtained by mapping the resultant model into the frequency domain using the probing method [9].

The nonparametric approach is often referred to as frequency-domain Volterra system identification and is based on the observation that the Volterra model of nonlinear systems is linear in terms of the unknown Volterra kernels, which, in the frequency domain, corresponds to a linear relation between the output frequency response and linear, quadratic, and higher order GFRFs.
This linear relationship allows the use of a least squares (LS) approach to solve for the GFRFs.
Several researchers [10–12] have used this method to estimate the GFRFs.
But they usually made the assumption that it is known a priori that the system under study can be represented by just two or three terms.
However, such information is rarely available a priori.
